title-group.article-title: Retinal vessel abnormalities predict coronary artery diseases

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: There are limited data supporting an association between retinal microvascular changes and cardiovascular mortality, but there is no convincing evidence of an independent or direct association with atherosclerosis in coronary artery disease (CAD) patients. The present study examines the relationship between retinal microvascular changes and angiographic findings.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Patients who were candidates for angiography were, at first, referred to the ophthalmology department for the determination of the severity of retinal atherosclerosis based on the Scheie classification. Angiography was carried out afterwards. Each patient completed a questionnaire, also providing information on risk factors. For each patient, the Gensini score was calculated using angiography findings.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: A total of 168 patients (99 males and 69 females) with a mean age of 55.3±11.9 years were included in this study. The results show a significant association between CAD severity and retinal artery atherosclerosis (r = 0.47, p = 0.0001). In multiple regression analyses with CAD severity (using Gensini scoring) as a dependent variable, we observed a significant association between atherosclerosis scores based on Scheie criteria (β=0.31, p<0.0001), diabetes mellitus (DM) (β=0.29, p<0.0001), hypertension (β=0.23, p<0.0001), smoking (β=0.20, p<0.0001), and age (β=0.15, p<0.0001).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: The results demonstrate that fundoscopic changes might be a predictor of CADs. However, more well-designed studies to verify these results are still needed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Atherosclerosis is one of the main causes of death worldwide. It is characterized by significant societal morbidity and huge health care costs.1-3 Also, with the increasing incidence of this disease, the need for appropriate diagnostic tools for early detection grows.4

Atherosclerosis is a systemic disease that affects many arterial beds in the body, such as the retinal vasculature.4,5 Some studies show the associations of retinal arteriolar abnormalities with clinical and subclinical manifestations of atherosclerosis and with risk factors for vascular disease.6 Structural changes in the retinal vasculature are considered as main indicators of systemic hypertensive damage and life prognosis.7,8 Overall, there are inadequate studies regarding the prediction of the role of the retinal arteriolar factor in the detection of coronary artery disease (CAD).9,10

This study was designed to determine the frequency of retinal arteriolar findings in patients with CAD, with coronary angiography serving as the reference standard. These parameters were also compared.

sec.title: Participants and study design
sec.p: Two hundred and twenty-one patients known, or suspected, to have CAD who were referred to the researchers’ center for coronary angiography from March 2008 to March 2009 were invited to participate in the study. Before undergoing angiography, all patients were referred to the ophthalmology department for ophthalmoscopy examination. Patients who were not willing to join in the study or did not submit to the ophthalmoscopy test were excluded; the remaining 168 patients who gave informed consent were included.

Risk factors encountered during the study include: (1) hypertension (self-reported history of hypertension and/or use of antihypertensive medication or a blood pressure >140/90 mmHg), (2) smoking, (3) dyslipidemia (high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol <40 mg/dL, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol >100 mg/dL or anti-hypercholesterolemic treatment) and (4) family history of coronary heart disease (CHD) (in men, a first-degree relative <55 years of age; in women, a first-degree relative <65 years of age). The pretest likelihood of CAD was anticipated by consideration of age, diabetes mellitus (DM), cholesterol to HDL ratio, gender, and smoking.11
This study complies with the Declaration of Helsinki and is confirmed by the Institutional Ethics Committee of Tehran University of Medical Sciences.

sec.title: Coronary arteriography
sec.p: Coronary angiograms were visually analyzed and scored by two expert observers who had no knowledge of the patients’ retinal artery status. The methods of coronary angiography and Gensini score measurement were similar to those used in the study of Tedeschi-Reiner et al.9 The Gensini score describes to stenosis of the coronary arteries as 1 for 1% to 25%; 2 for 26% to 50%; 4 for 51% to 75%; 8 for 76% to 90%; 16 for 91% to 99%, and 32 for complete occlusion. The score is then multiplied by a factor that indicates the importance of the lesion’s position in the coronary vasculature. For example, 5 for the left main coronary artery and 2.5 for the proximal left anterior descending or proximal left circumflex artery.

sec.title: Ophthalmoscopy
sec.p: For all 168 patients, the eye examination was done by direct ophthalmoscopy performed after pupil dilitation by the same ophthalmologist who did not know any data about the subjects, particularly their coronary artery condition. The extent and severity of atherosclerotic vascular lesions in the retinal arteries were classified according to the Scheie classification.12 Grade 1 is a broadening of the light reflex from the artery, with scanty or no arteriovenous compression (earliest sign of retinal artery atherosclerosis). Grade 2 is the same as stage 1, but more prominent. In Grade 3, the arteries have a “copper wire” pattern, the arteriovenous compression is much greater and severe atherosclerotic changes of the retinal arteries are seen. In Grade 4, the arteries have a “silver wire” pattern and the arteriovenous crossing changes are the most serious (Table 1). The detailed terminology of retinopathy lesions were as described in the references.10,13,14

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: A two-tailed t-test was used to compare the mean values between groups. The continuous variables are expressed as mean ± SD and the categorical variables are expressed in absolute values and percentages. Student’s t-test was used to differentiate between continuous variables and the Chi-square test was used to analyze categorical variables. Moreover, Pearson’s and Spearman’s tests were used to test for associations between the two numerical variables. Multiple regression analysis was also used to ascertain the relationship of the severity of CAD (Gensini score), which is a dependent variable, with age, gender and CAD risk factors, which are independent variables. The statistical analysis was performed with the use of the Statistical Package for the Social Science (SPSS), Version 18 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL). A p-value <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The study included 69 females and 99 males (mean age: 55.3±11.9; range: 42-76 years).

Thirty (17.9%) patients had DM, 31 (18.5%) had hypertension, 41 (24.4%) had dyslipidemia and 33 (19.6%) were smokers (Table 2). All variables except for the number of smokers were not statistically significant between the two genders.

sec.p: The mean left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was 49.50±6.80%. The average Gensini score was 34.3±35.6.
The most common retinal microvascular abnormality was focal arteriolar narrowing in 87 patients (51.8%), followed by a broadening of the light reflex in 46 patients (27.4%) (Table 3)(Figures 1, 2)

sec.p: A significant association was found between CAD severity and retinal artery atherosclerosis (Spearman’s correlation coefficient(r) = 0.47, p = 0.0001) (Figure 3). Also, the Gensini scores between patients with various ophthalmoscopic findings had a significant difference (p<0.05) (Table 5).

sec.p: According to multiple regression analyses with CAD severity (using the Gensini score) as a dependent variable, the atherosclerosis score using the Scheie criteria (β=0.31, p<0.0001), diabetes mellitus (β=0.29, p<0.0001), hypertension (β=0.23, p<0.0001), smoking (β=0.20, p<0.0001) and age (β=0.15, p<0.0001) were significantly associated.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results show that retinal vessel atherosclerosis correlates strongly with atherosclerotic changes in coronary arteries. In the literature, there are limited studies on this subject. In a similar study involving 109 patients (aged 40–80 years) who underwent coronary angiography for suspected CAD, the degree of retinal arterial atherosclerosis was correlated strongly with the extent and severity of CAD. Because the same findings may be observed in patients with hypertension, hypertensive patients were excluded.9 The available data on this issue are mainly performed in population-based patients, while this study was performed in the patient group.

In a study by Wong et al., there is a strong correlation between retinal arteriolar narrowing and incident CAD in healthy middle-aged people. A more prominent microvascular role in the development of CAD in women than in men is also noted.15

Another study analyzed whether retinal vascular signs contribute to the prediction of CAD over and above the Framingham risk score in 9155 people without diabetes who were selected from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) study. After a mean of 8.8 years of follow-up, 700 incident CAD events were recorded. Women with wider retinal venular caliber and narrower retinal arteriolar caliber had a higher risk of incident CAD after adjusting for the Framingham risk score variables. It was concluded that, although retinal vascular caliber independently predicted CAD risk in women, the incremental predictive capability over that of the Framingham model was modest and unlikely to translate significantly into clinical practice.10

In a systemic review analysis to determine the association between retinal vessel caliber and risk of CAD, six population-based prospective cohort studies were identified. These studies show that proportional hazard models were constructed for retinal vessel caliber and incident CAD in women and men while adjusting for traditional CAD risk factors. In total, 2219 (10.0%) incident CAD events were recorded for 22,159 individuals (mean age of 62 years) free of CAD who were observed for 5–14 years. Retinal vessel caliber changes (wider retinal venules and narrower arterioles) were each associated with an increased risk of CAD in women, but not in men.16

In other studies, the predictor values of smaller retinal arterioles and larger venules in CAD and stroke mortality were assessed. The pooled data were obtained from the Beaver Dam Eye Study (4926 participants, 43–86 years old) and the Blue Mountains Eye Study (3654 participants, 49–97 years old). These studies concluded that the retinal vessel diameter may predict CAD risk and stroke-related deaths in middle-aged persons.17

A similar relationship was obtained in a population-based cohort study of 3654 Australians aged >49 years and it was concluded that microvascular disease processes may have a role in CAD development in middle-aged people, particularly in women.18

Moreover, previous smaller studies have reported associations between retinal microvascular lesions, prevalent strokes, incident ischemic strokes,19 carotid20 and lower extremity artery atherosclerosis.9,14

There are probable mechanisms that explain our study results in nature. Atherosclerotic changes in the retinal arteries are considered in the thickening of the arterial wall and lipid precipitation in the intima is often associated with fibrosis and even with the calcification of larger arteries.9 Retinal arteriolar narrowing is thought to be an early indicator of microvascular damage due to aging, hypertension17 and other processes and it reproduces intimal thickening and medial hyperplasia, hyalinization and sclerosis.17 Because similar pathological features are also seen in the coronary and renal arterioles of persons with hypertension, changes in the retinal arterioles may offer useful evidence regarding the state of the systemic microcirculation in health and in disease. Wider retinal venules are associated with cardiovascular risk factors, including systemic inflammatory markers.17

In a study comprising 5979 persons aged 45–84 years, the retinal vascular caliber was measured and summarized from digital retinal photographs. Standard cardiovascular risk factors, including biomarkers of inflammation, e.g., high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP), interleukin-6 (IL-6), and plasma fibrinogen and endothelial dysfunction, e.g., soluble intercellular adhesion molecule–1 (sICAM-1) and plasminogen activator inhibitor–1 (PAI-1) were assessed. It was concluded that retinal arteriolar and venular caliber are associated with a range of cardiovascular risk factors, including hypertension, diabetes, measures of obesity and dyslipidemia. Venular caliber is also associated with systemic inflammation.6 In addition, retinal abnormalities were related to various markers of inflammation, consistent with microvascular pathology.19

The key role of inflammation in the development of CAD and atherosclerosis is demonstrated in the literature.21 Immune cells dominate early atherosclerotic lesions; their effector molecules accelerate the progression of the lesions and activation of inflammation can elicit acute coronary syndromes. Atherosclerosis, the main cause of CAD, is an inflammatory disease in which immune mechanisms interact with metabolic risk factors to initiate, propagate and activate lesions in the arterial tree.4,22

Our findings of independent associations between retinal vessel diameter and CHD support the concept that retinal vessel diameter may reflect lifetime cumulative effects of various vascular processes on the microvasculature and may, thus, be a novel biomarker of CHD risk.

Finally, our study had some drawbacks. The patients in this study were referred from a university-affiliated community hospital, limiting the extrapolation of the findings. Another limitation is that our data do not provide possible relating factors between coronary microvascular disease and CAD; however, further well-designed studies are needed.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results demonstrate that fundoscopic changes might be a predictor of CADs. However, more well-designed studies to verify these results are still needed.
